chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should aim to make presidential elections track the national will more closely while keeping states as meaningful partners in administering and certifying results. A workable compromise is to replace winner-take-all with proportional allocation of each state’s electors, paired with a national baseline for ballot access, counting, audits, and recount triggers so disputes are predictable and limited. If no candidate wins a clear majority of the national vote, a uniform runoff or ranked-choice tabulation could provide a decisive outcome without hinging on a few battleground states.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should make presidential elections track the will of voters more closely while preserving a meaningful role for states and avoiding sudden, destabilizing change. A practical bridge is to curb winner-take-all by moving toward proportional allocation of electors within states (or a national popular-vote compact as an alternative path), alongside uniform, transparent national standards for ballot access, counting, recounts, and post‑election audits. The goal is simple, trusted rules that reduce swing-state distortion, encourage broad coalition-building, and ensure every lawful vote feels meaningful whether cast in a small town or a major city.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Any reform should make the presidential winner match the will of voters more closely while keeping a meaningful role for states so small towns, big cities, and everyone in between feel represented. A workable bridge is to curb winner-take-all by moving to proportional allocation of electors (or a national popular vote via an interstate compact) and pairing it with a clear national standard for ballot access, counting, audits, and recounts. Adding a ranked-choice or runoff option can ensure the winner has broad support and reduce razor-thin disputes, while keeping the rules simple, transparent, and consistent nationwide.
